abstract.p: Arthroscopic surgery in the hip joint has historically lagged behind its counterparts in the shoulder and knee. However, the management of hip injuries in the athletic population has rapidly evolved over the past decade with our improved understanding of mechanical hip pathology as well as the marked improvement in imaging modalities and arthroscopic techniques. Current indications for hip arthroscopic surgery may include symptomatic labral tears, femoroacetabular impingement (FAI), hip capsular laxity/instability, chondral lesions, disorders of the peritrochanteric or deep gluteal space, septic joint, loose bodies, and ligamentum teres injuries. Furthermore, hip arthroscopic surgery is developing an increasingly important role as an adjunct diagnostic and therapeutic tool in conjunction with open femoral and/or periacetabular osteotomy for complex hip deformities.

Arthroscopic techniques have evolved to allow for effective and comprehensive treatment of various hip deformities. Techniques for extensile arthroscopic capsulotomies have allowed for improved central and peripheral compartment exposure and access for labral takedown, refixation, treatment of chondral injury, and osteochondroplasty of the femoral head-neck junction and acetabular rim. While favorable short-term and midterm clinical outcomes have been reported after arthroscopic treatment of prearthritic hip lesions, greater long-term follow-up is necessary to assess the efficacy of hip arthroscopic surgery in altering the natural history and progressive degenerative changes associated with FAI.

body.p: Unlike arthroscopic surgery of the knee and shoulder, hip arthroscopic surgery has only recently evolved as a viable intervention for prearthritic hip lesions over the past decade. First introduced in a cadaveric model by Dr Michael Samuel Burman in 1931, it was believed that visualization was extremely limited and that inserting a needle safely into the joint between the femoral head and acetabulum was close to impossible without considerable iatrogenic injury.14 The anatomic constraints, proximity of neurovascular structures, and lack of dedicated hip-specific distractors all contributed to a lack of experience with this procedure. Improvements in imaging technology and the evolution of arthroscopic techniques and instrumentation have facilitated the use of arthroscopic surgery as a powerful diagnostic and therapeutic tool.

sec.title: Clinical Evaluation
sec.p: Pain around the hip joint is notoriously difficult to diagnose. Although it is common to attribute hip pain to soft tissue strains or contusions, it is important to differentiate between intra-articular and extra-articular hip pathological abnormalities. The differential diagnosis should include bony and articular injuries such as femoral, pelvic, or acetabular fractures; stress fractures or reactions; hip dislocations or subluxations; avascular necrosis; cartilage injuries; and labral tears. A thorough evaluation is necessary to help determine the cause of discomfort because pain can also be the result of neurological irritation, bursitis, snapping hip from the iliopsoas or iliotibial band, or piriformis or hamstring syndromes. Additionally, pain can be referred from the lumbar or sacral spine and the genitourinary tract. Intra-abdominal and abdominal wall lesions should also be considered.

Careful attention to patient history is a critical component of the diagnostic work-up. The location, timing, onset, nature (clicking, catching, instability, decreased performance), and precipitating factors are all important.55 Intra-articular pain can be present in the anterior groin or thigh, buttock, greater trochanter, and even the medial knee. Byrd13 described the “C” sign in which patients cup their hands around the greater trochanter to demonstrate deep interior hip pain. Patients occasionally describe a specific traumatic event; however, most will report an insidious onset of symptoms.

sec.title: Physical Examination
sec.p: Unlike other joints, there is no recognized systematic hip evaluation protocol to help prevent a missed diagnosis. There have been many tests developed throughout the years, but there is minimal research to support their effectiveness for physicians. Given this lack of a systematic approach, the senior author (B.T.K.) has designed a “layered approach” to understanding the underlying etiological factors contributing to pain around the hip joint and associated hemipelvis. The 4 described layers are the osteochondral, intra-articular, muscular, and neural layers.

The osteochondral layer includes the femur, pelvis, and acetabulum, which provide joint congruence and normal joint kinematics. Abnormalities within this layer can be subdivided into 3 distinct categories: (1) static overload, (2) dynamic impingement, and (3) dynamic instability. Structural variations resulting in static overload include lateral or anterior acetabular undercoverage/dysplasia, femoral anteversion, and femoral valgus that lead to abnormal stress and asymmetric loads between the femoral head and acetabular socket in the axially loaded position.26

Dynamic factors may contribute to hip pain as abnormal stress and contact between the femoral head and acetabular rim occur with hip motion. When the functional range of motion is greater than the amount of physiological motion allowed by the hip, forceful anterior contact occurring at the end range of internal rotation may lead to dynamic instability in the form of subtle posterior hip subluxation, which occurs as the femoral head levers out of the hip socket. These mechanical stresses lead to reactive hip pain related to insufficient congruency or impingement between the head and socket, leading to asymmetric wear of the chondral surfaces of the acetabulum and femoral head with or without associated instability of the hip. Thus, the osteochondral layer has a direct effect on the intra-articular layer that includes the labrum, joint capsule, ligamentous complex, and ligamentum teres, all of which contribute to the static stability of the hip joint. Injuries that can result include labral injuries, ligamentum teres tears, capsular instability, and various ligament tears.

The muscular layer is the contractile layer of the hip and hemipelvis. It comprises all the muscles around the hemipelvis including the lumbosacral and pelvic floor musculature that provides dynamic stability and muscular balance to the hip, pelvis, and trunk. Abnormal mechanics within the osteochondral layer can lead to increased stresses of the sacroiliac joint, pubic symphysis, and ischium as well as secondary increases in the strains imparted to the muscles that attach to these pelvic structures. Compensatory core muscle dysfunction can affect any of the muscles crossing the hip joint but commonly manifests as tendinopathies involving the rectus abdominis, adductor longus, and pubic aponeurosis (athletic pubalgia).

The neural layer includes the thoracolumbosacral plexus, lumbopelvic tissue, and lower extremity structures. Compensatory injuries within this layer include nerve compression and pain syndromes, neuromuscular dysfunction, and spine referral patterns. Commonly involved nerves include the ilioinguinal, iliohypogastric, genitofemoral, and pudendal nerves.

The physical examination should begin with an assessment of gait and posture with a focus on limb length inequality, pelvic obliquity, foot progression angle, muscle contracture, and scoliosis. Generally, intra-articular lesions will not present with palpable pain, but palpation should be performed to localize any tenderness and identify any gross muscular atrophy.9 Active and passive ranges of motion should be assessed with the patient lying supine with the hips flexed, noting any asymmetry of motion. Care must be taken to stabilize the pelvis by extending the contralateral leg, with the pelvis level to the examination table. This is important to avoid an overestimation of primary hip motion secondary to rotation of the hemipelvis or lumbosacral spine. Those with femoroacetabular impingement (FAI) with acetabular retroversion usually can flex their hip to 90° to 95°. With the hip in this flexed position, the patient will have limited internal rotation as well as asymmetric external rotation compared with the contralateral leg.58 Finally, a thorough neurological and vascular evaluation should be performed (Table 1).101

caption.p: Physical Examination Technique Incorporating 5 Different Positions101

tr.td: Craig test: rotate limb until greater trochanter is parallel to floor
Gait: swing, stance, foot progression, pelvis
Impingement test: FADIR (flexion, adduction, and internal rotation)
Ely test: flex knee and draw lower leg into thigh
FABER (flexion, abduction, and external rotation) test
Lateral rim impingement: flexion to extension in abduction

sec.p: Being able to differentiate between intra-articular and extra-articular lesions is paramount to the physical examination of the patient with hip pain. To rule out any lower back problems, the Patrick, or FABER (flexion, abduction, and external rotation), test as well as the straight-leg raise test can assess for sacroiliac abnormalities or lumbar nerve irritation from a herniated disc, respectively. The FABER test places the affected limb in the “figure-of-4” position with the ankle resting on the contralateral leg. This places the anterosuperior rim of the femoral neck against the 12-o’clock position of the acetabular rim. The examiner then presses down on the affected leg, with pain being an indicator of a positive test result. Groin pain can indicate an iliopsoas strain, posterior hip discomfort implies sacroiliac joint disorders, and lateral hip pain can suggest FAI.87,94 The straight-leg raise test is performed with the patient lying supine and the leg straight off the table. If the patient experiences a recurrence of radiating pain along a dermatomal distribution at an angle of 30° to 70°, the test finding is positive, and a herniated disk is likely the cause of the pain.64

Other sources of discomfort to rule out include muscle contractures or fascial tightness about the hip. The Thomas test can help determine the presence of hip flexion contracture by eliminating lumbar lordosis on the perceived hip extension. By having the patient in the supine position and the contralateral hip flexed, the painful hip can be flexed and extended to assess for snapping. In a prone patient, the Ely test has the patient flex the affected knee to bring the foot toward the buttocks. A positive test result suggesting rectus femoris contracture occurs when knee flexion causes the pelvis to tilt and raise the buttocks from the table. The Ober test examines the patient in the lateral position, and the examiner places a stabilizing hand on the patient’s hip and lifts the affected leg straight up while extending the hip. Once the supportive hand of the examiner is removed, the affected leg should be able to adduct. A test result is determined to be positive when the leg stays abducted and is not able to passively adduct past the midline of the body, thus signifying iliotibial band or fascia lata tightness.

Once extra-articular causes of injury have been assessed, the examination should shift to focus on injuries within the hip joint. A quick, specific test for intra-articular lesions is passive log rolling of the affected lower extremity to move the femoral head within the acetabulum and the surrounding capsule to assess for discomfort.13 One of the most reliable and sensitive examinations for labral tears or FAI is the anterior impingement test.58 This test requires the physician to flex the hip to 90° and adduct and internally rotate the hip. Patients with labral lesions or FAI will complain of deep anterior groin pain with decreased motion.91 These maneuvers can cause contact between the femoral neck and anterosuperior acetabular rim, the most common location of acetabular labral tears. Mechanical symptoms can also be elicited by performing a resisted leg raise in the supine position (Stinchfield test) as the leg is raised to 45° with the examiner placing downward force with the hand just proximal to the knee. This can indicate an intra-articular problem as the psoas places pressure on the anterolateral labrum. The McCarthy hip extension test is another test used to assess for an anterior labral tear. The affected hip is rolled in arcs of internal and external rotation, while the hip is brought from flexion to extension. The test finding is positive when the patient’s pain is re-created when the hip is extended in external rotation and then in internal rotation.73 Finally, the posterior impingement test can assess posterior impingement lesions or cartilage degeneration. The patient lies supine with the contralateral hip flexed and held in position with his or her hands, while the affected limb is extended and externally rotated. Buttock pain can be produced when the femoral head contacts the posterior acetabular cartilage and rim.87,94

sec.title: Imaging
sec.p: Imaging traditionally begins with the use of radiographs, which should include an anteroposterior (AP) pelvic radiograph, a lateral (cross-table or Dunn view) radiograph, and a false profile radiograph. Inconsistencies can be present because of patient positioning.51 For the AP pelvic radiograph, it is important to have the x-ray beam center over the body in line with the pubic symphysis and coccyx. In male patients, it has been noted that the symphysis and sacrococcygeal junction should be 32 mm, while it should be 47 mm for female patients to best assess acetabular version.102 Additionally, symmetry of the obturator foramen should be assessed to ensure proper rotation. Subtle changes in pelvic tilt or obliquity can limit the evaluation and result in considerable errors in the evaluation of acetabular retroversion deformity. The femoral head should be covered by the normal acetabulum, with the anterior and posterior walls meeting at the lateral edge. Considerations to assess on the AP radiograph are included in Table 2.

caption.p: Signs of Osseous Abnormalities to Assess While Evaluating Plain Radiographs

tr.td: Crossover sign: An indication of acetabular retroversion in which the anterior and posterior walls of the acetabulum cross over each other
Posterior wall sign: Another sign of acetabular retroversion in which the posterior wall is medial to the center of the femoral head
Coxa profunda: Medial wall of the acetabulum lies at or medial to the ilioischial line
Protrusio acetabuli: Femoral head crosses the ilioischial line

sec.p: Lateral imaging can consist of a cross-table lateral or a Dunn lateral view (an AP view of the hip in 90° of flexion, 25° of abduction, and no rotation). These views can help to evaluate cam-type impingement, femoral head asphericity, and insufficient head-neck offset. The false profile view is also important to define the coverage of the anterior aspect of the femoral head. As Wenger et al112 concluded, 87% of patients with labral tears had at least 1 osseous abnormality on radiographs; therefore, plain radiographs should be evaluated for bony dysmorphisms. Areas to assess on plain radiographs for these osseous dysmorphisms are included in Table 3 and Figures 1, 2, and 3.

caption.p: Important Radiographic Considerations in the Evaluation of Femoroacetabular Impingement

tr.td: α angle: This angle can be determined on anteroposterior (AP) and lateral views of the hip. It is defined as the angle subtended between the midline of the femoral neck and a line connecting the center of the femoral head to the point along the head-neck junction that first deviates from the sphericity of the femoral head. An elevated value above 50° may be consistent with a cam impingement. On AP and lateral views, elevated values indicate a superolateral and anterior cam deformity, respectively (Figure 1).

Center-edge angle: The center-edge angle of Wilberg is determined by the angle subtended between a vertical line (orthogonal to the line defined by the inferior aspect of the ischial tuberosities) and a line connecting the center of the femoral head and the lateral aspect of the acetabulum. A measure less than 25° may be consistent with dysplasia (Figure 2A).

Crossover sign: This sign has been associated with cephalad acetabular retroversion on AP pelvic radiographs and is characterized by the anterior rim of the acetabulum projecting more laterally than the posterior rim. This relationship corrects more distally, resulting in the appearance of a “crossover” between the anterior and posterior walls on a well-positioned AP pelvic radiograph (Figure 2B).

Femoral head-neck offset: The offset is determined on a lateral view of the hip. A line is drawn through the center of the long axis of the femoral neck. A parallel line is drawn tangent to the anterior-most aspect of the femoral neck, and another parallel line is drawn tangent to the anterior aspect of the femoral head. The distance between these lines defines the offset and is normally greater than 10 mm. Loss of offset may be consistent with femoral impingement morphology.

Tönnis angle: This angle is determined by identifying the sourcil. The sourcil is the sclerotic weightbearing portion of the superior acetabulum. The medial and lateral extents of the sourcil are connected with a line, and the angle subtended between this line and a horizontal line parallel to one connecting the inferior aspect of the ischial tuberosities are determined. An angle greater than 10° may be consistent with dysplasia (Figure 3).

caption.p: The α angle can be determined on anteroposterior (A) and lateral (B) views of the hip. It is defined as the angle subtended between the midline of the femoral neck and a line connecting the center of the femoral head to the point along the head-neck junction that first deviates from the sphericity of the femoral head.

(A) The center-edge angle of Wilberg is determined by the angle subtended between a vertical line (orthogonal to the line defined by the inferior aspect of the ischial tuberosities) and a line connecting the center of the femoral head and the lateral aspect of the acetabulum. (B) The crossover sign has been associated with cephalad acetabular retroversion on an anteroposterior (AP) pelvic radiograph and is characterized by the anterior rim of the acetabulum projecting more laterally than the posterior rim. This relationship corrects more distally, resulting in the appearance of a “crossover” between the anterior (solid line) and posterior (thin dotted line) walls on a well-positioned AP pelvic radiograph.

The Tönnis angle, a, is determined by identifying the sourcil. The medial and lateral extents of the sourcil are connected with a line, and the angle subtended between this line and a horizontal line parallel to one connecting the inferior aspect of the ischial tuberosities, b, is determined.

sec.p: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) can help to supplement radiographs. It is the preferred modality for intra-articular lesions because of its excellent visualization of the labrum and cartilage as well as the surrounding soft tissue. In addition to plain MRI, magnetic resonance arthrography (MRA) adds a gadolinium-based contrast agent to enhance imaging of the labrum by distending the joint and allowing for separation of the labrum from the capsule and the bony acetabulum. Indeed, MRA has a sensitivity and accuracy from 92% to 100% and 93% to 96%, respectively.21,37,108

Although MRA has been found to be an important diagnostic tool for detecting the location and extent of labral tears,24 there have been concerns because it is an invasive procedure with greater associated costs and risks. An MRI protocol has been developed using noncontrast imaging that can identify labral and chondral disorders noninvasively76 (Table 4).

caption.p: Three Planes of Imaging for Magnetic Resonance Imaging and What to Assess

tr.td: • Weightbearing portion of the acetabulum and femoral head
• Weightbearing, suprafoveal margin of the femoral head
• Tendinous insertion of the gluteus minimus and medius
• Muscle bellies of the obturator internus and externus, quadratus femoris, and adductors
• Posterior labrum: associated with previous hip subluxation or dislocation
• Anterolateral portion of the femoral neck: quantify α angle for cam impingement
• Regional neurovascular bundles (femoral and obturator) and sciatic nerve

sec.p: Computed tomography (CT) is also a valuable imaging tool in the preoperative assessment of patients with symptomatic mechanical hip pathological abnormalities. Labral tears rarely occur in the absence of bony abnormalities, and research has revealed that failing to address these may ultimately lead to treatment failure.44,88 In an evaluation of 135 consecutive patients diagnosed with a hip labral tear, CT confirmed that 122 patients had associated structural abnormalities.25 Of these patients, 67 (55%) had a combination of radiographic osseous abnormalities, with the most common combination being an α angle greater than 55° and acetabular retroversion.39,102 Recognizing these bony abnormalities is critical to make an accurate diagnosis and thereby define a treatment plan that will address all contributory factors to symptomatic hip impingement.

sec.title: Current Indications and Management
sec.p: Current indications for arthroscopic hip surgery include the diagnosis and/or treatment of symptomatic acetabular labral tears, FAI, loose bodies, chondral injuries, joint sepsis, ruptured ligamentum teres, psoas impingement, disorders of the peritrochanteric space, and external snapping hip (coxa saltans). Furthermore, hip arthroscopic surgery is developing an increasingly important role as an adjunct diagnostic and therapeutic tool in conjunction with open femoral and/or periacetabular osteotomy for dysplasia and complex hip deformities.38,56 While the utility and versatility of arthroscopic surgery have rapidly evolved with improved exposure and instrumentation of the central and peripheral components, its efficacy is directly dependent on the careful and accurate definition of the mechanical hip deformity. Patients are typically considered to be candidates for hip arthroscopic surgery if they have refractory hip pain that has failed to respond to nonoperative treatment modalities with positive clinical signs and concordant imaging findings.

One of the most common indications for hip arthroscopic surgery is labral damage in the absence of significant degenerative changes of the articular surfaces. The labrum functions as a seal that allows for continual lubrication of the hip joint, which contributes to the overall health of the articular cartilage.33 The presence of this seal indirectly permits the labrum to function as a shock absorber that helps to deepen the hip joint to give this joint more stability, particularly at extreme hip motions such as hip flexion.34 It facilitates uniform pressure distribution, helps in the production of synovial fluid, and provides proprioceptive feedback.57 Treatment of labral tears and their associated injuries is extremely important for hip preservation in young adults, as recent research has shown the association between the presence of an acetabular labral tear and the early onset of osteoarthritis of the hip.35,74 To best treat labral tears, however, the underlying causes must be defined and treated as well.

sec.title: Traumatic Labral Tears
sec.p: Patients can incur these injuries with major trauma or benign mechanisms such as minor twisting or slipping events as well as chronic repetitive activities such as in athletes whose activities demand hyperflexion of the hip. These patients usually complain of anterior groin pain that can refer to the gluteal or trochanteric regions. Pain often has an insidious onset that is sharp and can be aggravated by activity such as prolonged standing, sitting, walking, or pivoting. Several studies have shown that 48% to 95% of labral tears are often associated with damage to the acetabular cartilage as well as the early onset of osteoarthritis.3,4,75,97

After patients undergo an initial trial of nonoperative management, surgical treatment strategies should be designed with the goal of preserving all functional labral tissue either with selective debridement with preservation or anatomic labral refixation for those tears with robust tissue quality and good healing potential. There are some early data suggesting that labral reconstruction using either autograft or allograft tissue may also be a viable solution for patients with ossified labral tissue, severe labral deficiency, or prior labral resections with persistent symptoms. There is good vascularity to the labrum on the capsular side; meanwhile, there is minimal blood flow to the labrum on the articular side.53 As a result, the healing potential of the labrum is greatest at the peripheral capsulolabral junction. Recent research has shown that there is often bony dysmorphism that contributes to this labral abnormality, and a failure to address this substantially increases the risk for clinical failure and the need for revision surgery.44,88

sec.title: Femoroacetabular Impingement
sec.p: Ganz et al39 recognized FAI as the predominant cause of labral tears in nondysplastic hips and described it as a preosteoarthritic condition of the hip. Cam-type impingement is caused by an abnormal shear force between an aspherical femoral head and a normal acetabulum during hip flexion and internal rotation.104 This abutment on the acetabular rim can displace the labrum toward the capsule, thus causing tears that are perpendicular to the articular surface in the labral transition zone between the fibrocartilage labrum and the articular hyaline cartilage.4 Characteristic cartilage damage occurs over the anterosuperior weightbearing portion of the acetabular dome.

Pincer-type impingement is secondary to acetabular overcoverage, which results in pathological contact between the normal femoral head and this prominent portion of the acetabulum. This causes crushing of the labrum between the femoral neck and acetabulum. The labrum fails first, which causes eventual labral ossification and further exacerbates this overcoverage.39,103 There is characteristic chondral damage that causes a “contrecoup” pattern of cartilage loss from the posteromedial femoral head and the corresponding posteroinferior portion of the acetabulum secondary to a levering effect associated with terminal hip motion.99 These chondral lesions are generally less severe than those caused by cam-type lesions (Figure 4).

caption.p: Biomechanics of hip impingement as seen on axial view of the hip joint. (A) A normal hip. (B) Reduced femoral head-neck offset (cam-type impingement). (C) Excessive overcoverage of the femoral head (pincer-type impingement). (D) Combination of cam and pincer types of impingement. (From Beaule PE, O’Neill M, Rakhra K. Acetabular labral tears. J Bone Joint Surg Am. 2009;91:701-710. Reprinted with permission from The Journal of Bone and Joint Surgery [http://jbjs.org].)

sec.p: Beck et al4 examined 302 cases of FAI and found that 5% had an isolated pincer lesion, 9% had an isolated cam lesion, and 86% had a combination of these 2 abnormalities. Philippon and Schenker87 found mixed FAI patterns to be the predominant cause of hip pain among athletes with complaints of decreased hip range of motion as well as impaired athletic performance. Athletes in the following sports were most affected: ice hockey, soccer, football, and ballet. Comprehensive treatment of both femoral- and acetabular-sided lesions is necessary to achieve a successful clinical outcome and objective improvement in hip motion.44,87

sec.title: Traumatic Hip Instability
sec.p: Traumatic hip instability can range from subtle, low-energy hip subluxations to high-energy hip dislocations. In the setting of hip dislocations, arthroscopic surgery has been found to play a role in the removal of loose bodies and the management of chondral injuries and labral disorders.78 This injury most often occurs from motor vehicle accidents; however, they have been described in athletic competition with athletes falling forward onto their knees with their hips flexed or a blow from behind while an athlete is on all 4 limbs.

After immediate reduction, there is debate regarding the use of hip arthroscopic surgery. Previous studies have shown that concentric reduction on plain radiographs and/or loose bodies on CT do not correlate with a hip joint without debris.70,78,86,114 Despite animal studies illustrating that the presence of chondral debris can lead to premature osteoarthritis, no clinical evidence supports this finding.29 Patients with nonconcentric hip reductions or intra-articular fragments may require early arthroscopic management; however, there is increased concern for fluid extravasation that requires close intraoperative monitoring. For patients without these indications after hip dislocation, they should be followed with serial clinical visits. If they have discomfort or instability 6 weeks after their injury, an MRI scan should be ordered to evaluate for chondral or labral injuries to assess for pathological changes that might need operative intervention.

sec.title: Atraumatic Hip Instability
sec.p: It has been proposed that laxity in capsular tissue or abnormal bony structures may predispose an athlete to hip instability.6,86 In the athlete with FAI, functional range of motion required in athletic competition is often greater than the limited physiological motion allowed by cam and/or pincer lesions. Increasing flexion and internal rotation may result in anterior engagement between the cam lesion and the anterior acetabulum, which results in levering of the femoral head posteriorly. This can lead to failure of the soft tissue and osseous structures with a subsequent posterior acetabular rim fracture and posterior capsulolabral tear, analogous to a posterior bony Bankart lesion of the shoulder.100 Anterior labral tears have also occurred as part of the spectrum of injury after posterior hip subluxation or dislocation.32 The proposed mechanism is a labral crush injury at the point where the cam lesion engages the anterior acetabulum and labrum. Occasionally, a posterior hip subluxation or dislocation event may be the first manifestation of occult FAI in competitive athletes.32

This has been noted to be difficult to recognize on physical examination; however, specific tests such as the posterior impingement test, dial test, and traction have been described as useful examinations.8 As previously described, the posterior impingement test can be utilized with the patient supine on the examination table and the physician extending the hip with external rotation. A positive test result is elicited with apprehension or discomfort with this motion, indicating soft tissue deficiencies of the anterior hip capsule.83 The dial test examines the patient in the supine position with the examiner internally rotating the affected limb and then releasing it to allow the limb to fall into external rotation. If this leg rotates more than 45° from vertical in the axial plane with no end point, this is considered a positive test finding and is indicative of capsular laxity.83 Finally, apprehension with traction of the affected leg might be a sign of instability.

Indeed, MRI often demonstrates a characteristic triad: hemarthrosis, fracture of the posterior portion of the acetabulum rim, and iliofemoral ligament disruption.77 If patients do not exhibit signs of avascular necrosis on MRI at 6 to 12 weeks after injury, they may return to sport after they have achieved full, painless range of motion and strength. Given that avascular necrosis can develop several months to years after the index injury, it is still important to monitor for the development of symptoms in these athletes.

sec.title: Degenerative Joint Disease
sec.p: There is controversy surrounding hip arthroscopic surgery in the setting of osteoarthritis. McCarthy and Lee72 found that debriding osteophytes or a degenerative, frayed labrum can help improve mechanical symptoms in patients with early hip disease. Meanwhile, Walton et al111 reported that osteoarthritic patients were found to have significantly worse outcomes. The results of multiple systematic reviews report significantly inferior clinical outcomes in the setting of severe preoperative pain23 and degenerative changes.5,23,81 Preoperative radiographic space narrowing of greater than 50%, less than 2 mm of joint space remaining,61 or generalized intraoperative severe cartilage lesions85 portend high rates of arthroplasty within 3 years of hip arthroscopic surgery.45 In our opinion, hip arthroscopic surgery in the setting of chondral wear should be approached with even more stringent criteria. The presence of any joint space narrowing relative to the contralateral side or the presence of reciprocal regions of focal full-thickness wear on both the femoral head and the acetabulum on MRI should be approached with considerable caution.

sec.title: Hip Dysplasia
sec.p: In a patient with hip dysplasia, the shallow acetabulum can cause subluxation that places the labrum stretching against the femoral head. It has been found that in these patients, there are morphological labral differences that set it apart from FAI.39,63 Dysplastic hips have been shown to have distinctly hypertrophic labrums with myxoid degeneration and/or detachment from the osseous rim, while FAI is more likely to have undersurface tears with no hypertrophy.58,63

Byrd and Jones19 showed that debridement could provide symptomatic relief; however, arthroscopic surgery should also be approached with caution in this population. Labral refixation may be reasonable in cases of subtle dysplasia in symptomatic athletes, but extensive debridement with capsulotomy may result in iatrogenic instability and greater dysfunction. In cases of significant dysplasia, arthroscopic surgery may be a diagnostic and therapeutic tool to address chondral and labral lesions. However, it should be accompanied by a more definitive procedure, such as periacetabular osteotomy, to address the underlying primary mechanical problem and static overload.

sec.title: Psoas Impingement and/or Snapping
sec.p: Psoas impingement is commonly seen in ballet dancers as well as figure skaters and ice hockey players. Compression of the psoas tendon on the anterior capsule and labrum can cause an atypical anteromedial labral tear. An audible popping can often be reproduced on examination by the patient and examiner. As previously described, the Thomas test can help in the evaluation. With the patient supine and the contralateral hip flexed, the affected hip is flexed and then extended with the examiner’s hand on the anterior hip to assess for snapping. For selected patients with a symptomatic internal snapping hip, arthroscopic surgery can improve symptoms and eliminate painful snapping with labral debridement/repair and associated tenotomy or fractional lengthening of the iliopsoas tendon at the site of compression. However, these cases can usually be treated nonoperatively, and if fractional lengthening is performed, up to 30% of patients may be left with functional weakness and pain if the psoas is acting as a dynamic stabilizer of the joint. Patients with excessive femoral anteversion or anterior dysplasia are at the greatest risk for inferior outcomes after psoas tenotomy, and in general, this procedure should be avoided in this patient group.30 Even in the absence of excessive femoral anteversion, a symptomatic internal snapping hip can be effectively treated by decompressing the medial aspect of the anterior inferior iliac spine and the iliopectineal eminence in the majority of cases. This approach creates a “psoas tunnel” and effectively reduces the compressive forces of the psoas against the anterior capsule and labrum without altering muscle function.

sec.title: Peritrochanteric Space Disorders
sec.p: Disorders of the lateral compartment, or peritrochanteric space, include tears of the gluteus medius or minimus, external snapping hip (coxa saltans), or trochanteric bursitis. Tears of the gluteus medius or minimus are analogous to tears of the rotator cuff in the shoulder, both demonstrating an increasing incidence with advanced age caused by degenerative changes in the tendon and enthesis.11,50 Patients may present with lateral hip pain, a Trendelenburg sign, and pain and weakness of the abductors. As described earlier, the Ober test can also assess for gluteus medius tears or contracture when the affected limb is examined in the neutral position. This test is performed with the patient in the lateral position; the knee flexes with the affected leg in the neutral position. The leg is then abducted by the examiner. When this force is removed and the leg remains abducted, this is considered a positive test finding. An MRI scan can be confirmatory, demonstrating increased signal in the gluteus medius or minimus tendons with partial or complete detachment from their trochanteric facet with surrounding inflammation or edema.

External snapping hip syndrome occurs when the thickened posterior portion of the iliotibial band or anterior gluteus maximus tendon slides over the greater trochanter during hip flexion. Hip extension will then bring this thickened portion of tissue back over the greater trochanter, causing the snapping phenomenon. Diagnosis is evident when the patient is voluntarily able to reproduce this snapping. This disorder is common in running and cycling athletes.

Trochanteric bursitis is described as a chronic, aching discomfort over the lateral aspect in the region of the greater trochanter. This is usually easily diagnosed through history and physical examination as well as a response to corticosteroid injection into the bursa. Also, MRI can occasionally be helpful with increased signal intensity of the bursa.

sec.title: Surgical Management of Labral Tears and FAI
sec.p: Hip arthroscopic surgery can be successfully performed in both the supine and lateral decubitus positions. Portal positioning is critical to the success of the procedure. The standard portals are the anterior, anterolateral, and posterolateral portals. The anterior portal is placed at the intersection of a line drawn distally from the anterior superior iliac spine and a transverse line from the tip of the greater trochanter. This portal is in close proximity to the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve. Many surgeons have favored using a modified anterior portal slightly distal and lateral to this location to afford greater protection to the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve. The anterolateral and posterolateral (optional) portals are placed at the superior border of the greater trochanter at its anterior and posterior borders, respectively. By respecting these landmarks, important neurovascular structures can be avoided (Figure 5).

caption.p: (A) Anterior portal pathway. The portal penetrates the sartorius and rectus femoris muscles before entering the anterior capsule. Its course is almost tangential to the axis of the femoral nerve, lying only slightly closer at the level of the capsule. Inset (right), anterior view of the hip neurovascular structures. (B) Anterolateral portal pathway. The portal penetrates the gluteus medius muscle, entering the lateral capsule at its anterior margin. Inset (right), posterior view of the hip. The superior gluteal nerve lies well cephalad to this site. (C) Posterolateral portal pathway. The portal penetrates the gluteus medius and minimus muscles, entering the lateral capsule at its posterior margin. Image courtesy of Smith & Nephew.

sec.p: Once appropriate portal placement and labral visualization have been accomplished by means of an anterior capsulotomy, the labrum should be debrided of frayed, nonviable tissue. This can be performed with a variety of instruments including radiofrequency ablation, motorized shavers, and biters. The preserved tissue should be probed to assess whether there is enough healthy tissue to merit repair. The acetabular rim should then be prepared to bleeding bone with a motorized bur with fluoroscopic assistance as needed. Sutures are passed with the assistance of a suture penetrator or shuttle sutures. Refixation is best achieved using a noneverting vertical mattress stitch, which prevents labral deformity and preserves the suction seal function of the preserved tissue.54,60,62,101

In patients with labral injuries, it is important to not only treat the labrum but also address the underlying osseous abnormalities. Failure to address these deformities is the most common cause of failure and revision FAI surgery.44,88 Focal retroversion of the acetabulum (“pincer”) at the cranial aspect of the acetabulum should be treated before labral refixation.

The cam lesion is then treated in the peripheral compartment to restore normal femoral offset and sphericity. A technical challenge is to address this deformity circumferentially but also proximodistally to ensure complete and thorough treatment of any source of mechanical impingement. Up to a 30% resection of the head-neck junction can be performed without compromising the safe load-bearing capacity for the femoral neck and without increasing the risk of fractures.65 Dunn or extended neck lateral fluoroscopic images can help to guide the intraoperative resection. However, a dynamic examination under direct arthroscopic visualization is essential to confirm elimination of the impingement and improvement in functional range of motion.

sec.title: Labral Reconstruction
sec.p: In the event that the labral tear cannot be repaired primarily, labral reconstruction is an increasingly popular option to help restore the labral seal and reinstate physiological function within the hip joint. This is seen in patients with severe labral damage with complex tear patterns that are not amenable to fixation. Other situations include revision arthroscopic surgery in which there is insufficient labral tissue from prior labral debridement.

Several techniques involving autografts have been described including the use of the gracilis tendon,69 ligamentum teres capitus,105 and iliotibial band.84 Philippon et al84 reported on autograft iliotibial band reconstruction using an open harvest, and at 18-month follow-up, patients had improved modified Harris Hip Scores and patient satisfaction scores. One of the senior authors (M.A.T.) has described a labral reconstruction with an all-arthroscopic procedure with arthroscopic harvest of a portion of the indirect head of the rectus femoris to span a gap of labral deficiency between the 12- and 3-o’clock positions. This technique allows for the utilization of local tissue transplantation without the additional concern of donor site morbidity. It is important to note that regardless of technique, labral reconstruction can help to restore the hip’s capacity to function effectively and should be an option for labral lesions that are not amenable to repair.

sec.title: Surgical Management of Peritrochanteric Space Disorders
sec.p: The same portals used for the central and peripheral compartments can be utilized for peritrochanteric space lesions. The anterior portal is best placed 1 cm lateral to the anterior superior iliac spine in the interval between the sartorius and tensor fasciae latae. The cannula should be directed vertically into the peritrochanteric space with the leg in full extension and 10° to 15° of internal rotation. Slight abduction of the leg can be helpful to increase the potential space between the iliotibial band and the abductor and vastus musculature (Figure 6).

caption.p: Intraoperative set-up of portal placement for peritrochanteric space disorders of the left hip. The anterior portal (A) is placed between the sartorius and tensor fasciae latae. The distal lateral portal (B) is placed between the tip of the greater trochanter and the vastus tubercle along the anterior third of the greater trochanter. A third portal, the anterolateral portal (C), can be placed proximal to the tip of the greater trochanter in line with the distal posterior portal.

sec.p: Inspection of the gluteus minimus and medius is similar to the arthroscopic inspection of the rotator cuff of the shoulder. In the event of a repairable tear of one of these tendons, the edges should be debrided, and the insertion site should be prepared to a healthy, bleeding bony surface. Suture anchors are then placed into the tendon footprint in a standard fashion. The sutures are then passed through the edges of the tendon with a suture-passing device and tied under arthroscopic visualization with the assistance of an arthroscopic knot pusher.

For arthroscopic repair of gluteus medius tears, Voos et al109 prospectively evaluated 10 patients with lateral hip pain as well as abductor weakness. Of these patients, 6 patients had a fall mechanism, while the other 4 patients had an insidious onset that limited daily activities. After arthroscopic repair with a mean of 25 months’ follow-up, these patients had complete resolution of their pain as well as a return of motor strength.

In the case of a symptomatic or snapping iliotibial band, a release can be performed along the thickened posterolateral portion of the iliotibial band from the insertion to the tip of the greater trochanter. Both an ellipsoid excision of tissue or Z-type release have been described.49

sec.title: Capsulotomy Repair
sec.p: As previously discussed, an anterior capsulotomy connecting the anterolateral and anterior portals is usually performed at the onset of the procedure to help with visualization and instrument maneuverability within the central compartment and to assist in rim decompression and labral refixation. An additional T-cut can be performed in the peripheral compartment, taking advantage of the intermuscular interval between the iliocapsularis insertion on the medial limb of the iliofemoral ligament and the gluteus minimus insertion on the lateral limb of the iliofemoral ligament. This T-cut allows for preservation of the entire capsular envelope and allows for improved visualization superolaterally and distally through capsular retraction.

There is much debate as to how to address the capsule at the termination of the procedure, as there is no consensus within the literature. Many hip surgeons traditionally have not repaired the capsulotomy with favorable results and no significant sequelae.46 Additionally, it is believed that the capsulotomy may be therapeutic in the setting of preoperative stiffness.15,67 In a cadaveric study, Myers et al79 demonstrated that a careful repair of the capsulotomy helps to maintain translation and rotation of the hip and helps to avoid increased external rotation of the hip after arthroscopic surgery, which can cause increased inflammation. The senior authors (M.A.T., A.B., B.T.K.) believe that careful dissection of the capsule within intermuscular planes, and careful preservation of all extracapsular muscular tissue, allows for the most complete exposure and visualization of the cam deformity and ensures accurate and reproducible decompression and restoration offset. Furthermore, if a meticulous capsular dissection is performed, then restoration of normal capsular anatomy at the completion of the case can be easily achieved and can minimize the chance for iatrogenic postoperative instability or anterior capsular scarring. However, in some cases, the cam deformity is accessible with just the preliminary interportal cut, and the proximal-to-distal T-cut can be avoided with similar outcomes and bony reconstruction.

sec.title: Rehabilitation
sec.p: Postoperative rehabilitation protocols have been described in the literature for arthroscopic hip procedures involving labrum repairs or debridement and bony decompressions.27,28,40 Protected weightbearing is generally in place depending on the specifics of the procedure (labral repair/reconstruction or debridement and the amount of bone debrided if necessary) as well as the patient’s body mass and surgeon preference. Patients who undergo labral repair are allowed to ambulate with flatfoot weightbearing (FFWB) for 2 weeks and then advance as tolerated.90 Those who undergo osteoplasty with labral repair are restricted to FFWB for 3 weeks and then advanced to 50% weightbearing for 1 additional week to help establish motor control before full weightbearing as tolerated.110 Meanwhile, patients who undergo microfracture for full-thickness chondral lesions must abide by FFWB for 6 to 8 weeks.89 These precautions help to protect against iatrogenic fractures in the setting of a significant femoral osteoplasty. A brace may be used postoperatively to limit abduction and terminal flexion to protect a labral refixation. Additionally, an abduction pillow between the patient’s legs can be placed for sleeping to avoid stretch on the anterior capsule by limiting external rotation, particularly in the setting of a capsular plication or anterior capsular repair.

Some surgeons encourage the use of a continuous passive motion machine for the first 4 weeks for 2 to 4 hours daily.101 With the seat in the high position, patients are encouraged to start riding a stationary bike to maintain joint range of motion, circulation, and muscle strength without prolonging the inflammatory process. Muscle stretching can be initiated at 2 to 3 weeks beginning with the hamstrings and then progressing to the other muscles about the hip at 4 weeks. Hip flexor exercises, particularly straight-leg raises, are typically avoided for a minimum of 8 weeks because they can exacerbate pain and inflammation in the region of labral refixation and rim decompression.

With a slow progression to full strength training, a return to activity can typically occur over a 3- to 4-month period of time. Elite athletes have been shown to return to sport in as few as 12 weeks.92 However, more prolonged recovery times are expected in patients who had poor muscle tone before surgical intervention, more severe preoperative pain, increased time between the onset of symptoms and surgical intervention, the presence of a limp before surgery, and who have developed secondary core muscle dysfunction and/or neurological sequelae. In this subgroup of patients, a typical return to activity may take between 6 to 9 months. It is important that the patient has appropriate range of motion, strength, flexibility, and endurance independent of the postoperative duration before return to play is contemplated.

sec.title: Complications
sec.p: The incidence of complications reported after hip arthroscopic surgery is generally less than 1.5%.46 The major complications of hip arthroscopic surgery stem from traction-related nerve injuries and fluid management issues as well as iatrogenic chondral injuries. Other potential complications reported in the literature include deep venous thrombosis, septic arthritis, and iatrogenic hip dislocation and subluxation.7,12,22,46,68 Sampson96 reviewed complications associated with 530 hip scopes and found a complication rate of 6.4% (0.4% permanent complications). The most common traction injuries were transient (2-3 days) neurapraxias of the peroneal, femoral, sciatic, lateral femoral cutaneous, and pudendal nerves.

Rodeo et al95 presented one of the earliest reports of pressure necrosis of the foot, scrotum, and perineum. It is extremely important to be mindful of the amount of force as well as the duration of traction and allow the intermittent release of traction. Additionally, positioning of a large, well-padded peroneal post to distribute the forces across this region as well as padding of the foot should be employed. Both the duration of traction as well as the amount of force applied are related to postoperative neurapraxia. Traction times should be limited to 60 minutes if possible, although some literature supports safe traction up to 2 hours. The force of traction should generally not exceed 70 lb.66

Another major complication is fluid extravasation into the intrapelvic or intra-abdominal spaces. These complications have been reported with prolonged operative times or extra-articular surgery such as loose body removal or iliopsoas release. Bartlett et al2 reported a rare incidence of cardiac arrest after intra-abdominal extravasation after an arthroscopic loose body removal in a patient with an old acetabular fracture. As a result, ipsilateral acetabular fractures have been a relative contraindication for arthroscopic surgery. Additionally, Fowler and Owens36 described a case that led to an abdominal compartment syndrome requiring an exploratory laparotomy. It was hypothesized that the capsulotomy and subsequent psoas tenotomy allowed for an open track to be established between the hip joint and the pelvis that permitted the extravasation of fluid into the pelvis. They recommended saving this portion of the procedure until the end of the central compartment arthroscopic surgery to minimize fluid extravasation. The monitoring and treatment algorithm has been constructed59 (Table 5).

caption.p: Treatment Algorithm for Fluid Extravasation During Hip Arthroscopic Surgery

tr.td: • Continuous pH, urine output, and cardiac monitoring
• General surgery consult for exploratory laparotomy if abdominal compartment syndrome suspected

sec.p: Other complications such as osteonecrosis and femoral neck fractures have been described in case reports. Ayeni et al1 reported a minimally displaced femoral neck fracture sustained in a 51-year-old man 5 weeks after arthroscopic osteoplasty for FAI. This case illustrated that a fracture can occur even when the resection is within the guidelines and stresses the importance of protected weightbearing for 2 to 4 weeks after osteoplasty.

sec.title: Long-term Studies
sec.p: Until recently, only short-term follow-up clinical outcomes series after hip arthroscopic surgery were available. In the largest long-term study to date, McCarthy et al71 retrospectively reviewed 324 patients (340 hips) who underwent arthroscopic surgery for pain and/or catching. Of these patients, 106 patients (111 hips) had a minimum follow-up of 10 years (mean, 13 years). With conversion to total hip arthroplasty defined as a “failure,” survivorship among these hips was 63%. In this series, only the labral lesions were treated, with the underlying osseous deformities ignored. Favorable predictors of survivorship were Outerbridge grades I/II of the acetabulum and femoral head. When evaluated independently, femoral head cartilage damage was 2 times more likely to cause a failure than acetabular damage. Advanced patient age at arthroscopic surgery was a predictor of failure, as patients over 40 years of age were 3.6 times more likely to require arthroplasty during the study period.

Another long-term study by Byrd and Jones20 retrospectively reviewed 50 patients (52 hips) with a 10-year follow-up. This study showed the postoperative evolution of symptomatic relief as patients had improved modified Harris Hip Score outcomes with the greatest improvement over the first month. Results stabilized at approximately 3 months, with a continued gradual improvement throughout the first year. Scores were maintained at 2 years but diminished slightly at 5-year follow-up. However, 10-year results approached those of the 2-year level. Results were better in younger patients in their second, third, and fourth decades whose symptoms were present for less than 18 months. Additionally, it was found that at the time of the index procedure, the presence of arthritis was an indicator of poor prognosis (Tables 6 and 7).

sec.title: Systematic Reviews
sec.p: Systematic reviews of the literature have also been conducted to assess hip arthroscopic surgery. Bedi et al5 evaluated 19 studies that reviewed the use of hip arthroscopic surgery (12 studies) compared with open procedures (7 studies) for the management of labral tears and FAI. After arthroscopic care for labral tears, 67% to 100% of patients were satisfied with their results. Patients treated for labral tears and associated FAI did well, with 93% of patients returning to sport and with 78% continuing athletics at 1.5 years after surgery. This limited short-term review suggests that arthroscopic management is as effective as open techniques in achieving satisfactory clinical results for the treatment of labral and FAI pathological abnormalities. Additionally, Ng et al81 (23 studies: 20 level IV, 2 level III, and 1 level I) and Matsuda68 (18 studies: 14 level IV and 4 level III) performed systematic reviews to assess the efficacy of surgery for FAI and found agreement with the general conclusion of the previous study that both open and arthroscopic procedures achieve satisfactory results.

sec.title: Summary
sec.p: Hip arthroscopic surgery is a rapidly evolving, minimally invasive procedure for patients with intra-articular and peritrochanteric space disorders. With improvements in our understanding of mechanical hip pathology as well as improvements in imaging and arthroscopic instrumentation, the ability to address a variety of hip pathological abnormalities through an arthroscopic approach has expanded. In an appropriately selected patient, arthroscopic management of FAI has become an accepted therapeutic modality with relatively low complication rates. This procedure has been found to relieve pain and improve function in short-term studies in an otherwise healthy, active patient population. Poor prognostic factors to consider are increased patient age, advanced preoperative degenerative changes, and severe preoperative pain. Further long-term clinical studies as well as multicenter trials are necessary to define evidence-based rehabilitation protocols and to characterize the effect of these interventions on the natural history.
